questions.text: What was the primary cause of World War I?
questions.reason: The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary in 1914 was the immediate trigger of World War I.

questions.text: The United Nations was founded in:
questions.reason: The United Nations was founded in 1945 after World War II to replace the League of Nations, to stop wars between countries, and to provide a platform for dialogue.

questions.text: Who was the President of the United States during the majority of the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s?
questions.reason: Lyndon BJohnson was the President of the United States from 1963 to 1969, a significant portion of the Civil Rights Movement.

questions.text: The concept of separation of powers is most closely associated with which of the following documents?
questions.reason: The U.SConstitution introduced the principle of separation of powers into practice, providing the framework for the U.Sgovernment.

questions.text: What economic system is characterized by private or corporate ownership of goods and means of production?
questions.reason: Capitalism is characterized by private or corporate ownership of goods and means of production.

questions.text: The Industrial Revolution began in which country?
questions.reason: The Industrial Revolution began in the United Kingdom in the late 18th century.

questions.text: The Treaty of Versailles ended which conflict?
questions.reason: The Treaty of Versailles officially ended World War I.

questions.text: Who first proposed the idea of the separation of powers?
questions.reason: Montesquieu, a French philosopher, was the one who articulated the principle of separation of powers.

questions.text: The Great Wall of China was primarily built as a defense against:
questions.reason: The Great Wall of China was mainly built as a defense against invasions by the Mongols.

questions.text: The term "Cold War" refers to the political tension and non-combative rivalry that existed between which two superpowers?
questions.reason: The term "Cold War" refers to the political tension and non-combative rivalry that existed between the USA and the USSR from 1947 to 1991.

questions.text: The primary purpose of the Federal Reserve in the United States is to:

answers.b: Control the money supply and stabilize the economy

questions.answer_text: Control the money supply and stabilize the economy
questions.reason: The primary purpose of the Federal Reserve in the United States is to control the money supply to promote effectively the goals of maximum employment, stable prices, and moderate long-term interest rates.

questions.text: Which document declared the United States' independence from Great Britain?
questions.reason: The Declaration of Independence, adopted on July 4, 1776, declared the 13 American colonies independent from Great Britain.

questions.text: What was the main reason for the establishment of the United Nations?

answers.b: To maintain international peace and security

questions.answer_text: To maintain international peace and security

answers.b: The division between capitalist Western Europe and communist Eastern Europe during the Cold War
answers.c: The defense strategy of the Roman Empire
answers.d: The trade barrier policies of the United States in the 19th century

questions.answer_text: The division between capitalist Western Europe and communist Eastern Europe during the Cold War
questions.reason: The term "Iron Curtain" was used by Winston Churchill in his speech in 1946 to describe the division between free capitalist Western Europe and the communist Eastern Europe during the Cold War.

questions.text: The abolitionist movement in the United States focused on ending:
questions.reason: The abolitionist movement in the United States was a movement to end slavery.

questions.reason: In a democratic society, government officials are usually chosen by public vote or election.

questions.reason: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 in the United States primarily aimed to end racial discrimination.

questions.text: Which of the following forms of government is characterized by a single party or individual having unlimited power?
questions.reason: An autocracy is a system of government in which supreme power is concentrated in the hands of one person, whose decisions are subject to neither external legal restraints nor regularized mechanisms of popular control.

questions.reason: The principle of checks and balances allows each branch to control or check the other two, which balances power among them.

answers.d: Vice President of the United States

questions.reason: The Speaker of the House is the presiding officer of the House of Representatives.

questions.text: Who has the power to declare war?
questions.reason: The power to declare war is vested in Congress, although the President has the power to direct the military as Commander-in-Chief.

questions.text: What is the "rule of law"?

answers.a: The law applies only to certain people
answers.b: The government is above the law
answers.c: The law does not apply to the President
answers.d: No one is above the law

questions.answer_text: No one is above the law
questions.reason: The "rule of law" means that every person, no matter who they are, must follow the law.

questions.text: The right to a speedy trial is guaranteed under which amendment?
questions.reason: The Sixth Amendment guarantees the right to a speedy trial, among other rights related to criminal prosecutions.

questions.text: Which amendment to the U.SConstitution provides the right to bear arms?
questions.reason: The Second Amendment provides the right to bear arms.

questions.text: Which amendment guarantees the right to a trial by jury in civil cases?
questions.reason: The Seventh Amendment guarantees the right to a trial by jury in civil cases.

questions.text: Which amendment addresses the issue of congressional pay increases?
questions.reason: The Twenty-Seventh Amendment prohibits any law that increases or decreases the salary of members of Congress from taking effect until the start of the next set of terms of office for representatives.

questions.text: What does the Fifteenth Amendment guarantee?

answers.b: Voting rights regardless of race or color
answers.c: Protection against unreasonable searches and seizures

questions.answer_text: Voting rights regardless of race or color
questions.reason: The Fifteenth Amendment guarantees that the right to vote cannot be denied based on race, color, or previous condition of servitude.

questions.text: The idea of dividing powers between the state and national government is known as:
questions.reason: Federalism is the system of government in which power is divided between a central government and individual states.

questions.text: How many justices serve on the Supreme Court?
questions.reason: The Supreme Court is composed of nine justices, including one Chief Justice and eight Associate Justices.

questions.text: Who has the power to appoint Supreme Court justices?
questions.reason: The President has the power to nominate justices to the Supreme Court, but these appointments must be confirmed by the Senate.

questions.text: The power of the purse, or control over budget and taxes, resides with:
questions.reason: Congress, specifically the House of Representatives, holds the "power of the purse" and can tax and

questions.text: Who presides over the Senate?
questions.reason: The Vice President of the United States is the presiding officer of the Senate.

questions.text: What does the Tenth Amendment stipulate?

answers.a: Rights not delegated to the federal government are reserved for the states or the people

questions.answer_text: Rights not delegated to the federal government are reserved for the states or the people
questions.reason: This is the principle of the Tenth Amendment, which emphasizes federalism.

questions.text: The Fifth Amendment protects against:
questions.reason: The Fifth Amendment includes protections against self-incrimination.

questions.text: What does the Eighteenth Amendment prohibit?
questions.reason: The Eighteenth Amendment, also known as the Prohibition Amendment, prohibited the manufacture, sale, and transportation of alcoholic beverages.

questions.text: The Twentieth Amendment is also known as:
questions.reason: The Twentieth Amendment is known as the "Lame-Duck Amendment" as it shortens the time between Election Day and the inauguration of officials, reducing the lame-duck period.

questions.text: The Twenty-Second Amendment limits:
questions.reason: The Twenty-Second Amendment limits a person to two terms as President.

questions.text: The power to impeach a President lies with:
questions.reason: The House of Representatives has the sole power to impeach a President, but the Senate has the power to try all impeachments.

questions.text: The role of the federal bureaucracy falls under which branch of government?
questions.reason: The federal bureaucracy, which includes various departments and agencies, falls under the Executive Branch.

questions.text: How many voting members are in the House of Representatives?
questions.reason: The House of Representatives has 435 voting members.

questions.text: The idea that government is restricted in what it can do and individuals have rights the government cannot take away is known as:
questions.reason: Limited Government is the principle that the government is restricted in what it can do and that individuals have certain inalienable rights that the government cannot violate.

questions.text: The "Elastic Clause" of the Constitution refers to:

answers.a: The flexibility of the Constitution to adapt to modern needs
answers.b: The flexibility of the President to enforce laws as needed
answers.c: The ability of Congress to stretch its powers to meet needs not anticipated by the framers
answers.d: The ability of the Supreme Court to interpret the Constitution flexibly

questions.answer_text: The ability of Congress to stretch its powers to meet needs not anticipated by the framers
questions.reason: The "Elastic Clause," or "Necessary and Proper Clause," gives Congress the flexibility to carry out its enumerated powers.

questions.text: The Nineteenth Amendment granted voting rights to:
questions.reason: The Nineteenth Amendment granted women the right to vote.

questions.text: The First Amendment guarantees:

answers.b: The right to a speedy trial
answers.c: Freedom of speech, religion, press, assembly, and petition
answers.d: Protection from unreasonable searches and seizures

questions.answer_text: Freedom of speech, religion, press, assembly, and petition
questions.reason: The First Amendment guarantees these five freedoms.

questions.text: The Twenty-First Amendment is unique because it:

answers.a: Repeals a previous amendment (the Eighteenth Amendment)
answers.b: Grants women the right to vote

questions.reason: The Twenty-First Amendment both repealed the Eighteenth Amendment (Prohibition) and ended the prohibition of alcohol.

questions.text: What does the Fourteenth Amendment guarantee?
questions.reason: The Fourteenth Amendment guarantees equal protection under the law to all citizens.

questions.text: The Twenty-Fifth Amendment clarifies the:

answers.b: Procedure for presidential succession and disability

questions.answer_text: Procedure for presidential succession and disability
questions.reason: The Twenty-Fifth Amendment clarifies the order of presidential succession and procedures in the event of presidential disability.

questions.text: What is the primary responsibility of the Judicial Branch in the U.Sgovernment?
questions.reason: The Judicial Branch of the U.Sgovernment is primarily responsible for interpreting the law, including the Constitution and laws passed by Congress.

questions.text: The idea of "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness" is derived from which document?
questions.reason: The phrase "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness" is from the Declaration of Independence, a document that declared the colonies' independence from Britain.

questions.text: Which amendment to the U.SConstitution protects citizens from unreasonable searches and seizures?
questions.reason: The Fourth Amendment of the U.SConstitution protects citizens from unreasonable searches and seizures.

questions.text: The system of checks and balances is designed to ensure that:

answers.b: The Congress can control the Judiciary
answers.c: No one branch of government becomes too powerful
answers.d: The Judiciary controls both the Executive and Legislative branches

questions.answer_text: No one branch of government becomes too powerful
questions.reason: The system of checks and balances was designed to prevent any one branch of the U.Sgovernment from becoming too powerful.

questions.text: The right to a speedy trial is guaranteed by which amendment in the Bill of Rights?
questions.reason: The Sixth Amendment of the U.SConstitution guarantees the right to a speedy trial.

questions.text: The Senate has the power to:
questions.reason: The U.SSenate has the power to confirm Presidential appointments, such as Supreme Court justices and cabinet members.

questions.text: The Federalist Papers were written to:

answers.a: Convince the colonies to declare independence from Britain
answers.b: Gain support for the ratification of the U.SConstitution
answers.c: Argue for the adoption of the Bill of Rights

questions.answer_text: Gain support for the ratification of the U.SConstitution
questions.reason: The Federalist Papers were written to persuade the citizens and states to support the ratification of the U.SConstitution.

questions.text: The 19th Amendment to the U.SConstitution provided for:
questions.reason: The 19th Amendment to the U.SConstitution provided for women's suffrage, granting women the right to vote.

questions.text: What is the primary responsibility of the Executive Branch?
questions.reason: The primary responsibility of the Executive Branch is to enforce laws passed by the Legislative Branch.

questions.text: Which of the following is a power of the Legislative Branch?
questions.reason: The power to declare war is vested in the Legislative Branch, specifically, the Congress.

questions.text: The Tenth Amendment of the U.SConstitution is a key part of which constitutional principle?
questions.reason: The Tenth Amendment is a key part of the constitutional principle of federalism, asserting that powers not delegated to the U.Sby the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the states, are reserved to the states.

questions.text: The right to a trial by jury is established by which amendment to the U.SConstitution?
questions.reason: The Seventh Amendment to the U.SConstitution establishes the right to a trial by jury in civil cases.

questions.text: The U.SConstitution can be amended by a:

answers.b: Two-thirds vote in both houses of Congress
answers.c: Unanimous vote in the Supreme Court

questions.answer_text: Two-thirds vote in both houses of Congress
questions.reason: The U.SConstitution can be amended by a two-thirds vote in both the House of Representatives and the Senate, followed by ratification by three-fourths of the states.

questions.text: The power to regulate commerce with foreign nations is granted to which branch of government by the U.SConstitution?
questions.reason: The power to regulate commerce with foreign nations is granted to the Legislative Branch by the U.SConstitution.

questions.text: The "necessary and proper" clause in the U.SConstitution grants which of the following?
questions.reason: The "necessary and proper" clause in the U.SConstitution grants Congress the ability to make laws that are necessary and proper for carrying out its enumerated powers.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a check the Legislative Branch has on the Executive

answers.a: Override vetoes with a two-thirds vote

questions.reason: The power to declare executive actions unconstitutional is a check that the Judicial Branch has on the Executive Branch, not the Legislative Branch.

questions.text: The primary function of the U.SSupreme Court is to:
questions.reason: The primary function of the U.SSupreme Court is to interpret the Constitution.

questions.text: The Second Amendment of the U.SConstitution relates to:

answers.c: The right to a fair trial

questions.reason: The Second Amendment of the U.SConstitution pertains to the right to bear arms.

questions.text: The U.SConstitution's Preamble begins with which phrase?

answers.a: "We hold these truths to be self-evident..."
answers.c: "In order to form a more perfect union..."

questions.reason: The U.SConstitution's Preamble begins with the phrase "We the People..."

questions.text: The First Amendment of the U.SConstitution does NOT protect which of the following?

answers.d: Freedom from unreasonable searches and seizures

questions.answer_text: Freedom from unreasonable searches and seizures
questions.reason: The First Amendment of the U.SConstitution does not protect against unreasonable searches and seizures; that right is protected by the Fourth Amendment.

questions.text: The principle of "one person, one vote" is established by which constitutional amendment?
questions.reason: The principle of "one person, one vote" is most directly related to the Twenty-sixth Amendment, which lowered the voting age to 18, although all of the amendments listed have contributed to expanding voting rights.

questions.text: Which amendment to the U.SConstitution ended the practice of slavery?
questions.reason: The

questions.text: The "due process" clause in the U.SConstitution is part of which amendment?
questions.reason: The "due process" clause in the U.SConstitution is part of the Fifth Amendment.

questions.text: Which U.Sconstitutional amendment protects the right to freedom of speech?
questions.reason: The First Amendment to the U.SConstitution protects the right to freedom of speech.

questions.text: What does the Ninth Amendment to the U.SConstitution address?

answers.a: It declares that rights not listed in the Constitution are reserved for the states.
answers.b: It prohibits cruel and unusual punishment.
answers.c: It asserts that rights not listed in the Constitution are still protected.
answers.d: It gives women the right to vote.

questions.answer_text: It asserts that rights not listed in the Constitution are still protected.
questions.reason: The Ninth Amendment to the U.SConstitution addresses rights not specifically mentioned in the Constitution and asserts that people still have these rights.

questions.text: Which branch of government is responsible for writing bills and voting on whether they should become law?
questions.reason: The Legislative Branch of government is responsible for writing bills and voting on whether they should become law.

questions.text: The idea of "checks and balances" in the U.Sgovernment is designed to ensure that:
questions.reason: The idea of "checks and balances" in the U.Sgovernment is designed to ensure that no branch becomes too powerful by allowing each branch to check the power of the others.

questions.text: The 22nd Amendment to the U.SConstitution:

answers.b: Gave women the right to vote

answers.b: Another name for the Declaration of Independence
answers.d: The last ten amendments to the U.SConstitution

questions.answer_text: The first ten amendments to the U.SConstitution
questions.reason: The Bill of Rights is the term for the first ten amendments to the U.SConstitution.

questions.text: The U.SConstitution was signed in what year?
questions.reason: The U.SConstitution was signed in the year 1787.

questions.text: The right to remain silent when arrested or interrogated is protected under:
questions.reason: The right to remain silent when arrested or interrogated is protected under the Fifth Amendment to the U.SConstitution.

questions.text: The President's power to veto a bill passed by Congress is an example of:
questions.reason: The President's power to veto a bill passed by Congress is an example of checks and balances.

questions.text: Who is considered the "Father of the Constitution"?
questions.reason: James Madison is often referred to as the "Father of the Constitution" due to his key role in drafting and promoting the U.SConstitution.

questions.text: The U.SConstitution replaced which of the following documents?
questions.reason: The U.SConstitution replaced the Articles of Confederation.

questions.text: The 26th Amendment to the U.SConstitution:

answers.a: Lowered the voting age from 21 to 18

questions.answer_text: Lowered the voting age from 21 to 18
questions.reason: The 26th Amendment to the U.SConstitution lowered the voting age from 21 to 18.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the system of federalism?

answers.a: A system in which power is divided between the national and state governments
answers.b: A system in which all power is held by the national government
answers.c: A system in which all power is held by the state governments
answers.d: A system in which power is equally distributed among all citizens

questions.answer_text: A system in which power is divided between the national and state governments

questions.text: The "double jeopardy" clause in the U.SConstitution is part of which amendment?
questions.reason: The "double jeopardy" clause in the U.SConstitution, which protects against being tried twice for the same crime, is part of the Fifth Amendment.

questions.text: The right to petition the government is guaranteed in which amendment?
questions.reason: The right to petition the government is guaranteed in the First Amendment to the U.SConstitution.

questions.text: What does the Eighth Amendment to the U.SConstitution prohibit?
questions.reason: The Eighth Amendment to the U.SConstitution prohibits cruel and unusual punishment.

questions.text: Who has the power to declare war according to the U.SConstitution?
questions.reason: According to the U.SConstitution, the power to declare war is vested in Congress.
